awd_titl_txt: The 2020 Summer School on Random Matrices
awd_abstract_narration:
The 2020 Summer School on Random Matrices will take place at the University of Michigan during  June 15-26, 2020 period. This two-week summer school is intended for graduate students and junior postdocs who started working in the area of random matrix theory and related fields. 

There are several non-overlapping techniques in random matrix theory. The goal is to provide an opportunity for the participants to learn new techniques different from their own background. Four experts will deliver lectures series and there will be intensive group problem sessions. The Principal Investigators had organized the summer school in 2016 and 2018, and they plan to establish the summer school as a biannual event. The website for the summer school is http://web.eecs.umich.edu/~rajnrao/rmtschool/

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Random matrix theory is a subject in mathematics that has important applications in diverse fields of science and engineering, such as number theory, statistical physics, quantum gravity, statistics, and signal processing. The theory developed rapidly over the last thirty years in the mathematics community, and many new advanced techniques have been introduced. The PIs have been helping graduate students to learn these new advances by holding a biennial 2-week Summer School on Random Matrix Theory at the University of Michigan since 2016, skipping 2020 due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The project supported the 2022 Summer School held during June 13-24, 2022. The summer school featured four lecture series by experts on random matrix theory and related fields on the following four topics: (a) Random matrices and logarithmically correlated fields, (b) Geometric methods in random matrix theory, (c) Spin Glasses and Related Applications, (d) Invariant Ensembles and Orthogonal Polynomials. The summer school included daily problem-solving sessions, which the participants solved in groups, typed, and submitted every day. There were about fifty participants from more than thirty different institutions who were students in mathematics, statistics, applied mathematics, physics, and engineering. In addition to introducing new advanced methods to graduate students, the summer school provided excellent networking opportunities for students working in random matrix theory that will be valuable ad their careers advance.
